parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Available research provides limited specific data on the effects of compost over 20-year periods.
[Statement 2]: Several studies have examined the effects of compost on soil properties.
[Statement 3]: Municipal compost application to semi-arid soils greatly reduced soil loss and water runoff.
[Statement 4]: High rates of organic waste compost improved soil structure.
[Statement 5]: High rates of organic waste compost reduced soil loss.
[Statement 6]: Manure and compost applications consistently increased soil organic carbon levels across multiple studies.
[Statement 7]: Four studies showed higher carbon levels when manures were applied.
[Statement 8]: Compost application improved soil physical properties.
[Statement 9]: Compost application led to higher organic matter content.
[Statement 10]: Compost application resulted in larger soil aggregations.
[Statement 11]: Compost addition increased soil water retention in some studies.
[Statement 12]: Compost addition reduced water runoff.
[Statement 13]: Specific studies that track the effects of municipal waste compost continuously over 20-year periods are not available.
[Statement 14]: Most available evidence covers shorter-term impacts on soil physical properties, organic matter, and erosion control.
[Statement 15]: Most available evidence does not cover long-term fertility trends.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the long-term effects of using municipal waste compost on soil fertility over a 20-year period?
